cmd.cites.cmd.second.line.cite: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information § 3:18

prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: It is not necessarily that information be reduced to writing. In Quantum Management Services Ltd. v. Hann,[1] the court specifically restrained the defendants from exploiting information that they “had committed to memory”. Further, the English case of Printers & Finishers Ltd. v. Holloway[2] held that the mere fact that confidential information is not embodied in a document, but is carried away mentally, does not prevent the courts from ensuring its protection.[3]
An idea may be in either written or oral form. In Fraser v. Thames Television Ltd.,[4] the court concluded that:

… there is no reason in principle why an oral idea should not qualify for protection under the law of confidence, provided it meets the other criteria I discuss below. Neither the originality nor the quality of an idea is in any way affected by the form in which it is expressed. No doubt both the communication and the content of an oral idea may be more difficult to prove than in the case of a written idea, but difficulties of proof should not affect the principle any more than in any other branches of the law where similar problems arise (eg contract and defamation).
In addition, format may not be relevant either:

Nor do I accept counsel for the defendants' argument that an idea which is capable of development in more than one format is not entitled to protection. In my judgment the precise format is a matter for the writer to decide, and the fact that it is developable in more that one format in no way diminishes its intrinsic value.[5]

It would appear, however, that taking information contained in documents will increase the likelihood that the information will be found to be confidential in nature.[6] The fact that a party only takes computer or electronic copies of confidential information.[7] will not assist in repelling a claim.

Quantum Management Services Ltd. v. Hann (1989), 69 O.R. (2d) 26 at pp. 33-4, 43 B.L.R. 93 (H.C.J.), affd 11 O.R. (3d) 639, 45 C.P.R. (3d) 498 (C.A.). See also Monarch Messenger Services Ltd. v. Houlding (1984), 56 A.R. 147 at p. 152, 5 C.C.E.L. 219 (Q.B.), affd 13 C.C.E.L. xxxvi (Alta. C.A.).
Printers & Finishers Ltd. v. Holloway, [1965] 1 W.L.R. 1 (Ch.), at p. 5.

See also Robin-Nodwell Mfg. Ltd. v. Foremost Developments Ltd. (1966), 52 C.P.R. 244 at p. 249, 38 Fox Pat. C. 43 (Alta. S.C.); Reid and Sigrist Ltd. v. Moss and Mechanism Ltd. (1932), 49 R.P.C. 461 (Ch.); Terrapin Ltd. v. Builders' Supply Co. (Hayes) Ltd., [1967] R.P.C. 375 (Ch.), at p. 389.
Fraser v. Thames Television Ltd., [1983] 2 All E.R. 101 (Q.B.), at p. 121.
Fraser v. Thames Television Ltd., [1983] 2 All E.R. 101 (Q.B.).

Drake International Inc. v. Tennenbaum (1986), 10 C.P.R. (3d) 119 (Ont. H.C.J.); National Financial Brokerage Centre Inc. v. Investors Syndicate Ltd. (1985), 9 C.P.R. (3d) 489 (Que. S.C.), vard 9 C.P.R. (3d) 497 (Que. C.A.).
